page.title: 16Conservation in Alburgh
page.content: CONSERVATION The existing hedges round the fields are ancient and mixed, most of hawthorn with other species such as {sycamore,dogwood}and{holly}which have grown from seedlings over the years. Such hedges are vital habitats for many types of animals and birds, and afford a rich food supply for such fauna in the way of young shoots,nuts and berries.Black berries are gavered regularly by both animals and the people of the village to flavour their apples and to make bramble jelly and wines. Many wild flowers grow along the road sides and under the hedges, many of which are listed below.There is a great fear by environmentalists that the countinued use of insecticides and weed killer sprays will cause the loss of much such animals and plants.
